title: Binary architecture of the Na<sub>v</sub>1.2-β2 signaling complex
abstract: To investigate the mechanisms by which β-subunits influence Na<sub>v</sub> channel function, we solved the crystal structure of the β2 extracellular domain at 1.35Å. We combined these data with known bacterial Na<sub>v</sub> channel structural insights and novel functional studies to determine the interactions of specific residues in β2 with Na<sub>v</sub>1.2. We identified a flexible loop formed by <sup>72</sup>Cys and <sup>75</sup>Cys, a unique feature among the four β-subunit isoforms. Moreover, we found that <sup>55</sup>Cys helps to determine the influence of β2 on Na<sub>v</sub>1.2 toxin susceptibility. Further mutagenesis combined with the use of spider toxins reveals that <sup>55</sup>Cys forms a disulfide bond with <sup>910</sup>Cys in the Na<sub>v</sub>1.2 domain II pore loop, thereby suggesting a 1:1 stoichiometry. Our results also provide clues as to which disulfide bonds are formed between adjacent Na<sub>v</sub>1.2 <sup>912/918</sup>Cys residues. The concepts emerging from this work will help to form a model reflecting the β-subunit location in a Na<sub>v</sub> channel complex.
